repnme.cdata!:
India - Karnataka Rural Water Supply and
            Environmental Sanitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is rated as
            satisfactory, with project sustainability as likely. Both
            World Bank and Borrower performances are rated satisfactory
            overall: Despite weaknesses in project management, the
            project largely achieved both its physical targets and
            development objectives. Key lessons learned include the
            following: Ownership of the project design at the political,
            bureaucratic, and operational levels is a pre-requisite for
            project success. A conducive policy environment and
            willingmess to learn by doing are equally vital for success.
            Project design should respond to village aspirations for
            high service standards. The state level institutions should
            have the appropriate mandate and functional autonomy to play
            an effective facilitating role. The excessive turnover of
            key project staff has been a serious problem. Changing
            mandates and mindsets of state agencies, capacity building
            of all stakeholders by providing resources, and quality time
            need to be at the core of project design. Capacity building
            should address motivation, team building, and managerial
            issues for project staff. Implementation arrangements and
            procurement procedures should be aligned with community
            empowerment principles in participatory projects.
            Women's active participation improve local ownership
            and quality of implementation. Imaginative approaches have
            to be vigorously implemented to draw women into project activities.

repnme.cdata!:
Comparative study of the externally and
            government supported rural water supply and sanitation
            projects in Karnataka : final report

abstracts.cdata!:
The Government has made considerable
            efforts in the past decade to provide safe drinking water
            and sanitation facilities with the support of several
            multilateral, bilateral, and non-government organizations.
            With the onset of the international drinking water and
            sanitation decade, new initiatives have been taken in
            several states for the implementation of Integrated Rural
            Water Supply and Environmental Sanitation Projects (IRWS and
            ESP). A unique opportunity existed in Karnataka state to
            make a comparative study of externally assisted IRWS and ESP
            and government involvement in the sector. The interest in
            the study arose because of certain innovative policies,
            strategies, and approaches in project implementation and
            management. The study was conducted in two parts. The first
            part was· related to village level studies which were
            carried out in selected villages of the three externally
            assisted projects and the project under the government. The
            second part of the study was addressed to technical and
            management aspects including financial aspects and project
            implementation. The study reviewed the experiences of four
            rural water supply and sanitation programs (Danida,
            Netherlands, World Bank, and government supported) mainly
            with regard to project organization, project designs,
            components, criteria for selection, delivery mechanisms,
            financial arrangements, management process, operation and
            maintenance, functions of village water and sanitation
            committees (VWSCs), and program development strategies
            including behavioral changes.

repnme.cdata!:
Karnataka Integrated Rural Water Supply and
            Environmental Sanitation Project : status report

abstracts.cdata!:
This document presents a status report
            of the World Bank assisted Integrated Rural Water Supply and
            Environmental Sanitation Project for the state of Karnataka.
            The components of the pilot phase, details of training
            programs, course material preparation, meetings held,
            progress made, special features, and a month-wise report of
            courses conducted are detailed herein.

repnme.cdata!:
India - Karnataka Rural Water Supply and
            Environmental Sanitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This project is implemented in about
            twelve districts in the state of Karnataka and includes 1200
            villages. It raises the standard of living in rural areas by
            improving health and productivity . This is accomplished by
            expanding access to potable rural water supply systems and
            environmental sanitation facilities. Beneficiary communities
            are assuming full responsibility for operation and
            maintenance including cost recovery. These communities are
            also responsible for capital cost sharing for environment
            sanitation works. This project comprises the following
            components: (a) construction of new and rehabilitation of
            existing water supply schemes in 1,200 villages including
            leakage repair works, assistance for Public Health
            Engineering Department's borewell program, a water
            quality monitoring program and measures for groundwater
            recharge; (b) construction of environmental sanitation
            facilities including sullage drainage and, on a demand
            basis, pit latrines, washing platforms, cattle troughs,
            bathing cubicles, street bins and biogas plants; (c) health
            communication for creation of greater community awareness
            and demand for improved hygiene and environmental
            sanitation; and (d) institutional strengthening through
            community development programs (creation of village water
            supply and sanitation committees) and comprehensive training
            programs. NGOs comprise a large role in sanitation and
            health communication components.

docna.cdata!:
India - Karnataka Rural Water Supply and
            Environmental Sanitation Project

repnme.cdata!:
India - Integrated Rural Water Supply and
            Environmental Sanitation Project : socio-economic survey report

abstracts.cdata!:
The Integrated Rural Water Supply and
            Environmental Sanitation Project for the state of Karnataka
            in India was devised with the following goals: 1)
            augmentation of water supply, including rehabilitation of
            existing sources and ground water recharging; 2)
            environmental sanitation with latrines, village drainage and
            solid waste disposal; and 3) conducting a base-line survey
            on a sample basis and devising suitable messages to educate
            people in villages about water-borne and water-related
            diseases as part of a health education program. This report
            contains the details of a socio-economic base-line survey
            conducted to understand the pre-implementation situation in
            project areas, and also to be used as a resource while
            assessing changes over a period of time.

docna.cdata!:
India - Integrated Rural Water Supply and
            Environmental Sanitation Project : socio-economic survey report

display_title.display_title:

            Supply and Environmental Sanitation Project : socio-economic
